newsitem.title: FINLAND: No EU member proposing EMU delay -Finnish PM.
newsitem.headline: No EU member proposing EMU delay -Finnish PM.

text.p: No European Union member country is proposing that the start of economic and monetary union (EMU) be delayed, Finnish Prime Minister Paavo Lipponen said on Wednesday.
"Not one member country is proposing a delay," Lipponen, social democrat chairman, told a party meeting here.
"There are still many obstacles on the road to implementing EMU, but speculation about a delay of the project would only serve to undermine Finland's credibility," Lipponen said.
He said only Finland and Luxembourg last year fulfilled the EMU entry criteria.

"As a country fulfilling the requirements, Finland is a strong candidate to participate in EMU, among the first if sufficient conditions for the birth of EMU are in place a year from now," he said, referring to a planned summit of European Union heads of state and government in spring 1998. At that time, decisions will be made on which countries qualify to join the single currency, which is scheduled to start on January 1, 1999.

Talk of an EMU delay has recently intensified. But such speculation has been rejected by major EU countries, led by Germany and its influential central bank, the Bundesbank. --Helsinki newsroom +358-9-680 50 245, e-mail news@reuters.fi
